   Assessment and Plan
 PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 yoM with cardiac history as well as squamous cell
   on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. UNILATERAL EFFUSION: less likely CHF b/c of left-sided unilateral
   nature, though appears to have element of volume overload;
   parapneumonic effusion most likley, and would consider post-obstructive
   PNA given degree to which whole lung is affect and smoking history
   (thought had a normal PE four days ago at PCP's office per the pt).
   Also with question of hemotpysis, making mass and PE a possibility (esp
   with the hypoxia)
   -- f/u blood cultures
   -- will order UA/UCx for reported increased urinary output
   -- no CP, but will cycle enzymes
   -- will order TTE
   -- will treat empirically with azithro/ceftriaxone for CAP
   -- will obtain CTA after thoracentesis to evaluate for empyema,
   complicated effusion, etc.
   .
   #. COPD/ASTHMA: not sure which diagnosis he carries; records in
   computer incomplete
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs prn
   .
   #. AFIB:
   -- rate better now after fluids in ED
   -- will hold on dilt given hypotension; will restart as tolerated
   -- not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; will place on SSI
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel reg PRN
   .
   #. CONTACT: with patient, had friends who are [**Name (NI) 11045**] ([**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 16**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 484**] and
   [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11046**])
   .
   #. CODE: full, confrimed iwth patient, though he admits he hasn't
   really thought of it before.
   .
   #. DISPO: to remain in ICU overnight for obs, will call out if able to
   wean from O2 and stable
   ICU Care

   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute pleural effusion, acute coronary syndrome, and possibly post-obstructive pneumonia. The patient has a history of cardiac disease, squamous cell carcinoma on the face, and a smoking history.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6째C, heart rate of 81 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 113/46 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 92%. The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with wheezes on the right and rhonchi on the left, and the patient is using accessory muscles for breathing.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.1 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.1 g/dL, and creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated at 0.13 ng/mL, and his glucose level is 106 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show a whiteout of the left lung on a CXR, and a CTA is planned to evaluate for empyema and complicated effusion.

The patient's medical plan includes empiric treatment with azithromycin and ceftriaxone for community-acquired pneumonia, and a thoracentesis is planned to evaluate the pleural effusion. The patient's other medical conditions, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, atrial fibrillation, and diabetes, are being managed.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and the patient may require mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac disease and atrial fibrillation, and may be at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient has a diagnosis of acute pleural effusion and post-obstructive pneumonia, and may be at risk for further infection.
4. Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and may be at risk for bleeding complications, particularly with the use of anticoagulation therapy.
5. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of stroke and may be at risk for neurological complications such as seizures and stroke.

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU overnight for observation.

   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. UNILATERAL EFFUSION: less likely CHF b/c of left-sided unilateral
   nature, though appears to have element of volume overload;
   parapneumonic effusion most likley, and would consider post-obstructive
   PNA given degree to which whole lung is affect and smoking history
   (thought had a normal PE four days ago at PCP's office per the pt).
   Also with question of hemotpysis, making mass and PE a possibility (esp
   with the hypoxia).  s/p thoracentesis.
   -- D/C azithro/ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP
   -- Start Vanc/Cefepime for HAP
   -- f/u blood cultures, ucx
   -- will order TTE
   -- will obtain CT chest to evaluate for empyema, complicated effusion,
   etc.
   -- consult IP re: pleurocentesis of loculated effusion
   .
   #. COPD/ASTHMA: not sure which diagnosis he carries; records in
   computer incomplete
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs prn
   .
   #. AFIB:  Back in a fib with RVR
   -- rate better now after fluids in ED
   -- Diltiazem drip for rate control
   -- not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- start ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute pleural effusion, acute respiratory failure, and possible pulmonary embolism. The patient has a history of cardiac disease, squamous cell carcinoma on his face, and smoking.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6째C, heart rate of 81 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 113/46 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 92%.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral pitting edema, rales and high-pitched wheezes in the left lung, and a soft, non-tender abdomen. He has multiple skin lesions and areas of skin grafting on his forehead and head.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated troponin levels. Imaging studies reveal a whiteout of the left lung on chest X-ray, and microbiology results show no microorganisms on Gram stain of pleural fluid.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE: The patient has a unilateral effusion, which is less likely due to cardiac failure given the left-sided nature. Parapneumonic effusion is the most likely diagnosis, and post-obstructive pneumonia is also a possibility given the patient's smoking history and degree of lung involvement.
2. COPD/ASTHMA: The patient's diagnosis is unclear, and he is being continued on his home medications.
3. AFIB: The patient is in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate, which is being treated with a diltiazem drip. He is not on anticoagulation due to fall risk and possible gastrointestinal bleeding history.
4. DIABETES: The patient's home medications are being held, and he is receiving sliding scale insulin.
5. PPX: The patient is being continued on his home proton pump inhibitor, sucralfate, and bowel regimen.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure due to the acute pleural effusion and possible pulmonary embolism
* Cardiac complications due to atrial fibrillation and possible pulmonary embolism
* Infection due to the presence of a pleural effusion and possible pneumonia
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and anticoagulation therapy
* Fall risk due to the patient's history of falls and possible gastrointestinal bleeding

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, pneumonia, and atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient has a history of tachycardia, chest pain, and is experiencing respiratory distress. The patient is receiving antibiotic therapy with vancomycin, cefepime, and azithromycin, as well as anticoagulation therapy with heparin.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6째C (97.8째F)
* Heart rate: 133 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/64 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* SpO2: 95%

The patient has a pleural effusion, which is being treated with antibiotics and will be further evaluated by an interventional pulmonologist. The patient's AF is being managed with diltiazem and aspirin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a critical condition that requires immediate attention. If left untreated, it can lead to respiratory arrest and even death.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is a serious infection that can spread to other parts of the body, leading to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's AF can lead to embolic events, such as stroke or pulmonary embolism, if left untreated.
4. Pleural effusion: The patient's pleural effusion can lead to respiratory compromise and pleuritic chest pain if left untreated.
5. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusion increase the risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's AF and tachycardia increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and even cardiac arrest.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires immediate attention to address their respiratory failure, pneumonia, AF, and pleural effusion. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent potential medical complications and improve the patient's outcome.

Summary:

The patient, an 87-year-old man, is in the ICU with respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, and a complicated parapneumonic effusion. He has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and azithromycin. The patient's respiratory failure is not intubated, and he is receiving oxygen therapy. He has a tachycardic rhythm, with a heart rate in the 130s, and is experiencing chest pain. The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is complicated by the parapneumonic effusion, which may require further intervention, such as thoracentesis or chest tube insertion.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to complications such as stroke, cardiac arrest, or heart failure.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure, sepsis, or other complications.
4. Complicated Pleural Effusion: The patient's parapneumonic effusion may require further intervention, such as chest tube insertion or thoracentesis, to alleviate respiratory distress.
5. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure or cardiac complications.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's tachycardic rhythm and atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac arrest.
7. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and respiratory failure may lead to sepsis, which can cause multiple organ dysfunction.
8. Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate renal failure, which can worsen if not addressed promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics as prescribed.
2. Consult with an infectious disease specialist for further guidance on antibiotic therapy.
3. Consider thoracentesis or chest tube insertion to alleviate respiratory distress caused by the parapneumonic effusion.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if respiratory failure worsens.
5. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with anticoagulation and rate control medications.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider cardioversion if atrial fibrillation persists.
7. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist or critical care specialist for further guidance on respiratory management.
8. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider dialysis if renal failure worsens.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male with a cardiac history, admitted with shortness of breath and productive cough, and pink frothy sputum production. The patient has a significant amount of medical comorbidities, including atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, diabetes, and a history of smoking.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has a loculated effusion in the left lung, which is likely parapneumonic in nature. The patient has a history of smoking and has produced pink frothy sputum, which may indicate a mass or pulmonary embolism.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and is being treated with a Diltiazem drip for rate control. The patient has a history of cardiac disease, including left ventricular hypertrophy and mild mitral regurgitation.
* Renal: The patient has mild kidney disease, with a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL.
* Hematological: The patient has a white blood cell count of 10.1 x 10^9/L and a platelet count of 120 x 10^9/L.
* Neurological: The patient's neurological status is unclear, as the patient's responses to stimuli are not assessed.

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Antibiotics: Vanc/Cefepime for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)
* Antiarrhythmic: Diltiazem drip for atrial fibrillation
* Anticoagulant: None, due to fall risk and potential gastrointestinal bleeding history
* Anti-diabetic: Holding home PO meds, receiving SSI

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for HAP
* Ordering a CT chest to evaluate for empyema or complicated effusion
* Consulting interventional pulmonology for pleurocentesis of loculated effusion
* Continuing Diltiazem drip for rate control of atrial fibrillation
* Starting ASA 325mg daily
* Holding home PO meds for diabetes
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis or respiratory failure

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to the patient's respiratory comorbidities and loculated effusion
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure, due to the patient's atrial fibrillation and cardiac history
* Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or worsening chronic kidney disease, due to the patient's underlying kidney disease and potential fluid overload
* Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's underlying medical comorbidities and potential bacterial infections
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and potential anticoagulation therapy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male with a cardiac history, admitted to the ICU with shortness of breath, dyspnea, and pink frothy sputum production. The patient has a unilateral effusion on the left side, which is likely a parapneumonic effusion or post-obstructive pneumonia given the smoking history and degree of lung involvement. The patient has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and is receiving a Diltiazem drip for rate control.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.2째C, heart rate of 109 bpm, blood pressure of 103/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on high-flow nasal cannula. The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral pitting edema of the legs, soft and non-tender abdomen, and multiple skin lesions and areas of skin grafting.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.1 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 8.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 120 x 10^9/L. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L.

The patient's imaging studies show a left-sided effusion, with a moderate-sized pleural effusion on the left side, and a moderate-sized right-sided pleural effusion. The patient's echocardiogram shows mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size, moderate global left ventricular hypokinesis, and mild right ventricular cavity dilation with mild global free wall hypokinesis.

The patient's medical history is significant for cardiac disease, squamous cell carcinoma on the face, and smoking history. The patient's social history is significant for living alone and having friends who are available to contact.

Based on the patient's current condition, potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's unilateral effusion and hypoxia may lead to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and left ventricular hypokinesis may lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or thromboembolic events.
3. Infection: The patient's parapneumonic effusion or post-obstructive pneumonia may lead to infection, requiring antibiotics and further management.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may lead to further worsening of his respiratory status, requiring fluid management and diuretic therapy.
5. Thromboembolic events: The patient's atrial fibrillation and smoking history may increase his risk of thromboembolic events, requiring anticoagulation therapy.
6. Skin complications: The patient's multiple skin lesions and areas of skin grafting may lead to skin complications such as infection, pressure ulcers, or skin breakdown.

In conclusion, the patient requires close monitoring and management in the ICU to address his respiratory, cardiac, and infectious complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male with a cardiac history, admitted with shortness of breath, dyspnea, and pink frothy sputum production. He has a unilateral pleural effusion on the left side, which is likely parapneumonic or post-obstructive due to his smoking history. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
2. Pleural effusion, acute
3. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)/asthma
4. Systolic and likely diastolic heart failure
5. Diabetes
6. Post-operative ileus (PPX)

The patient is currently receiving treatment for:

1. HAP (Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia) with Vanc/Cefepime
2. AFIB with Diltiazem drip for rate control
3. Systolic and likely diastolic HF with Lasix 20mg IV x1 and monitoring of I/O with goal negative 1L
4. Diabetes with holding of home PO meds and SSI
5. PPX with home PPI, SQH, and bowel reg PRN

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Flash pulmonary edema due to fluid overload
2. Worsening of heart failure
3. Development of pneumonia
4. Respiratory failure
5. Cardiovascular complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest
6. Sepsis due to HAP or other infections
7. Diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome
8. Gastrointestinal complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued treatment for HAP with Vanc/Cefepime
2. Monitoring of blood cultures and UCx
3. Follow-up of final CT chest read
4. Monitoring of fluid status to prevent flash pulmonary edema
5. Discussion with the patient about intubation wishes and code status
6. Continued treatment for AFIB with Diltiazem drip
7. Monitoring of I/O with goal negative 1L
8. PM lytes to trend Cr and repletion of lytes prn
9. Holding of home PO meds for diabetes
10. Monitoring of PPX and bowel reg PRN.

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old male with a cardiac history, admitted with symptoms of shortness of breath and pink frothy sputum production. He has a unilateral pulmonary infiltrate, likely due to a parapneumonic effusion, and has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. The patient has a history of smoking and has undergone a thoracentesis, which showed a loculated pleural effusion. He has been started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and Diltiazem for rate control. The patient's condition is complicated by his cardiac history, hypokinesis, and likely diastolic and systolic dysfunction.

Potential medical complications:

1. Flash pulmonary edema: The patient's cardiac history and hypokinesis increase the risk of flash pulmonary edema, which could be exacerbated by fluid overload.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a unilateral pulmonary infiltrate and hypoxia, which could lead to respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypokinesis increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which could be exacerbated by medication or electrolyte imbalances.
4. Sepsis: The patient's HAP and loculated pleural effusion increase the risk of sepsis, which could be complicated by his cardiac history and hypokinesis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and his current use of anticoagulation medication increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's diabetes and current use of SSI medication increase the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis, which could be exacerbated by his cardiac history and hypokinesis.
7. Renal failure: The patient's cardiac history, hypokinesis, and likely diastolic and systolic dysfunction increase the risk of renal failure, which could be exacerbated by his current use of diuretics and antihypertensive medication.

Recommendations:

1. Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and monitor for signs of sepsis.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, including his atrial fibrillation and hypokinesis.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, including his oxygen saturation and pulmonary infiltrate.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid status closely, including his weight and fluid balance, to prevent flash pulmonary edema.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte status closely, including his potassium and magnesium levels, to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Consider consulting a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac management.
7. Consider consulting a pulmonologist to optimize the patient's respiratory management.
8. Monitor the patient's glucose levels closely and adjust his diabetes medication as needed.
9. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his diuretic medication as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 87-year-old male with a cardiac history and squamous cell carcinoma on his face, admitted with shortness of breath, dyspnea, and pink frothy sputum production. He has a unilateral pulmonary infiltrate on the left side, which is likely a parapneumonic effusion or post-obstructive pneumonia. The patient has atrial fibrillation, pleural effusion, and is at risk for flash pulmonary edema. He is on Vanc/Cefepime for hospital-acquired pneumonia and has been started on Metoprolol for rate control. The patient has a history of smoking and has refused VATS (video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery) for the loculated pleural effusion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Flash Pulmonary Edema: The patient's heart function is compromised, and he has a history of smoking, which increases his risk of developing flash pulmonary edema. Monitoring his fluid status and ensuring he does not go into fluid overload is crucial.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his compromised immune system, pneumonia, and pleural effusion.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation and compromised heart function increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised due to his pneumonia and pleural effusion, which may lead to respiratory failure.
5. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: The patient has diabetes, and his glycemic control is uncertain, which may lead to diabetic ketoacidosis.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and his anticoagulation status is uncertain, which may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to his compromised immune system and respiratory status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue Vanc/Cefepime for hospital-acquired pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's fluid status closely to prevent flash pulmonary edema.
3. Re-evaluate the patient's rate control and adjust his medication as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust his medication as needed.
5. Consider a palliative care consult to address the patient's pain and symptom management.
6. Re-evaluate the patient's anticoagulation status and adjust his medication as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 87-year-old male admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of pneumonia, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and atrial fibrillation (AFIB). The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3째C (99.1째F)
* Heart rate: 127 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 123/69 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* SpO2: 91%

The patient has a history of allergy to Percocet and Tylenol, and is currently receiving antibiotics, including ceftriaxone, cefipime, and vancomycin. The patient is also receiving metoprolol for AFIB and heparin for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Tachycardia
* Irregular heart rhythm
* Right and left lower extremity edema (1+)
* Soft and non-tender abdomen
* Warm skin
* Attentive and follows simple commands

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.1-9.5 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 120-139 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.5-2.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.13 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.7 mg/dL

Imaging studies show a large left-sided pneumonia with significant pleural effusion.

The patient's condition is complicated by:

* AFIB, which is not well-controlled
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia and parapneumonic effusion
* Pleural effusion, which is causing respiratory distress
* Right and left lower extremity edema, which may indicate fluid overload or cardiac dysfunction

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Worsening of respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation or ventilation
* Cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation or cardiac arrest
* Sepsis or septic shock due to bacterial pneumonia
* Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis due to immobility and hypercoagulability
* Renal failure due to hypotension, sepsis, or nephrotoxic medications
* Cardiac dysfunction or failure due to hypotension, sepsis, or cardiac disease

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral pulmonary infiltrate.
   Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to have
   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, urine culture
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- f/u IP recs, if any given the patient refused VATS
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn; start 1-2mg IV q4h prn
   -- Haldol for anxiety prn
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs prn (but watch use of albuterol given tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   -- Consider lasix if acute SOB but feel pneumonia is key factor, not
   volume overload (plus Cr bumped today)
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain.
   -- Diltiazem drip previously d/c
ed for rate control
   -- Changed metoprolol 50mg tid to IV 10mg q4h given difficulty taking
   PO
   -- Hope for autodiuresis with better rate control and forward flow;
   hold Lasix diuresis for today, re-evaluate tomorrow
   -- Consider lasix if acute SOB but feel pneumonia is key factor, not
   volume overload (plus Cr bumped today)[]
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.
   - Re-evaluate daily and need for Lasix diuresis; hold for today
   - Consider lasix if acute SOB
   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Haldol PRN
   - EKG today for QT prolongation
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus
   embolic phenomenom d/t afib without anticoagulation. Symptoms resolved
   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient
   - If clinical picture changes, consider CT head
   .
   # End of life care:
   - Palliative care c/s placed and staffed yesterday, f/u recs
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .
   # FEN:  Regular diet
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel regimen PRN
   .
   #. CONTACT: with patient, had friends who are [**Name (NI) 11045**] ([**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 16**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 484**] and
   [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11046**])
 they were updated yesterday ([**12-27**])
   .
   #. CODE: DNR/DNI.
   #. DISPO: in ICU, pending clinical improvement.

 PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral pulmonary infiltrate.
   Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to have
   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, urine culture
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- f/u IP recs, if any given the patient refused VATS
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn; start 1-2mg IV q4h prn
   -- Haldol for anxiety prn
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs prn (but watch use of albuterol given tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   -- Consider lasix if acute SOB but feel pneumonia is key factor, not
   volume overload (plus Cr bumped today)
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain.
   -- Diltiazem drip previously d/c
ed for rate control
   -- Changed metoprolol 50mg tid to IV 10mg q4h given difficulty taking
   PO
   -- Hope for autodiuresis with better rate control and forward flow;
   hold Lasix diuresis for today, re-evaluate tomorrow
   -- Consider lasix if acute SOB but feel pneumonia is key factor, not
   volume overload (plus Cr bumped today)[]
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.
   - Re-evaluate daily and need for Lasix diuresis; hold for today
   - Consider lasix if acute SOB
   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Haldol PRN
   - EKG today for QT prolongation
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus
   embolic phenomenom d/t afib without anticoagulation. Symptoms resolved
   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient
   - If clinical picture changes, consider CT head
   .
   # End of life care:
   - Palliative care c/s placed and staffed yesterday, f/u recs
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .
   # FEN:  Regular diet
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel regimen PRN
   .
   #. CONTACT: with patient, had friends who are [**Name (NI) 11045**] ([**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 16**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 484**] and
   [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11046**])
 they were updated yesterday ([**12-27**])
   .
   #. CODE: DNR/DNI.
   #. DISPO: in ICU, pending clinical improvement.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 87-year-old male with a history of cardiac disease and squamous cell carcinoma on the face, admitted with shortness of breath, DOE, and pink frothy sputum production. He has a pulmonary infiltrate on the left side, which is likely due to pneumonia, and has developed atrial fibrillation (AFIB) with rapid ventricular response. He has also developed acute pleural effusion, which was initially thought to be loculated but is now believed to be post-obstructive pneumonia. The patient has been treated with antibiotics and has been started on vasopressors to manage his hemodynamic status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require intubation and mechanical ventilation if his oxygenation and ventilation worsen.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may develop acute heart failure if his cardiac output decreases further.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his pneumonia and pleural effusion.
4. Stroke: The patient's AFIB and hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion may increase his risk of stroke.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's pleural effusion and AFIB may increase his risk of pulmonary embolism.
6. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels may indicate renal failure, which could worsen his overall condition.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and his history of gastrointestinal bleeding may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. End-of-life care: The patient's poor prognosis and lack of response to treatment may require consideration of end-of-life care, including palliative care and hospice services.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antiviral therapy as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation and mechanical ventilation if necessary.
3. Manage the patient's cardiac function with vasopressors and rate control medications.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke and pulmonary embolism.
6. Provide supportive care, including pain management and emotional support, to improve the patient's quality of life.
7. Consider end-of-life care options, including palliative care and hospice services, if the patient's condition worsens.

4. Respiratory failure: The patient's decreased SpO2 levels and need for non-invasive ventilation suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure.
5. Fluid overload: The patient has a history of fluid overload and may be at risk for further fluid accumulation, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiac status.
6. Sepsis: The patient has a history of smoking and a pulmonary infiltrate, which increases his risk of developing sepsis.
7. End-of-life care: The patient has been placed on palliative care and has a DNR/DNI code status, which suggests that he may be nearing the end of life.

The patient's laboratory results are significant for elevated troponin levels, which may indicate cardiac damage. His blood cultures and urine culture results are pending, and he has been started on vancomycin and cefepime for suspected HAP.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continuing vancomycin and cefepime for HAP
2. Monitoring fluid status carefully to prevent fluid overload
3. Re-evaluating the patient's cardiac status and adjusting treatment as needed
4. Providing palliative care and managing the patient's symptoms
5. Considering the use of diuretics, such as lasix, to manage fluid overload
6. Monitoring the patient's SpO2 levels and adjusting treatment as needed
7. Considering the use of antibiotics, such as azithromycin, to treat pneumonia

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition require close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old man admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to multilobar pneumonia. He has been on non-invasive ventilation (NIPPV) and is currently on a shovel mask plus nasal cannula. His oxygen saturation has slightly improved. The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFIB) and a right ventricular overload (RVR). He has a pleural effusion and altered mental status, but not delirium.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is ongoing, and he may require further interventions, such as intubation, to improve oxygenation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is not yet fully treated, and he may require additional antibiotics or other therapies to combat the infection.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's AFIB may lead to complications such as stroke, heart failure, or cardiac arrest if not properly managed.
4. Pleural Effusion: The patient's pleural effusion may require drainage or other interventions to alleviate symptoms and prevent complications.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be related to his pneumonia, AFIB, or other underlying conditions, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to respiratory failure or other complications.
7. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid overload may lead to complications such as heart failure, pulmonary edema, or kidney injury if not properly managed.
8. Infection: The patient's pneumonia may lead to secondary infections, such as sepsis or septic shock, if not properly managed.
9. Cardiac Complications: The patient's AFIB and RVR may lead to cardiac complications, such as heart failure, cardiac arrest, or stroke, if not properly managed.
10. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may progress to delirium if not properly managed, leading to further complications and increased risk of mortality.

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral pulmonary infiltrate.
   Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to have
   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, urine culture
   -- send sputum culture if starts bringing up sputum
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- 20 IV lasix this morning, goal -500cc today, given CXR, wheeze
   (?cardiac wheeze), pedal edema
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn 1-2mg IV q4h
   -- consider haldol for anxiety (as anxiety was trigger for hypoxia)
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs standing and prn (but cautious use of albuterol given
   tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain. s/p diltiazem gtt for rate control.
   -- Change IV to PO metoprolol (metoprolol 50mg tid) as taking PO
   without difficulty now
   -- Lasix this AM, as above
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.
   - Lasix as above, diuresis
   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Consider haldol as needed for agitation as that was previously
   related to desats
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus
   embolic phenomenom d/t afib without anticoagulation. Symptoms resolved
   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient
   - If clinical picture changes, consider CT head
   .
   # End of life care:
   - Palliative care c/s placed and staffed yesterday, f/u recs
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .
   # FEN:  Regular diet
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel regimen
 goal BM today
   .

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral pulmonary infiltrate.
   Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to have
   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, urine culture
   -- send sputum culture if starts bringing up sputum
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- 20 IV lasix this morning, goal -500cc today, given CXR, wheeze
   (?cardiac wheeze), pedal edema
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn 1-2mg IV q4h
   -- consider haldol for anxiety (as anxiety was trigger for hypoxia)
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs standing and prn (but cautious use of albuterol given
   tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain. s/p diltiazem gtt for rate control.
   -- Change IV to PO metoprolol (metoprolol 50mg tid) as taking PO
   without difficulty now
   -- Lasix this AM, as above
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.
   - Lasix as above, diuresis
   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Consider haldol as needed for agitation as that was previously
   related to desats
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus
   embolic phenomenom d/t afib without anticoagulation. Symptoms resolved
   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient
   - If clinical picture changes, consider CT head
   .
   # End of life care:
   - Palliative care c/s placed and staffed yesterday, f/u recs
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .
   # FEN:  Regular diet
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel regimen
 goal BM today

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male with a cardiac history and squamous cell carcinoma on his face, admitted with shortness of breath and pink frothy sputum production. The patient has undergone several interventions, including thoracentesis, computed tomography (CT) imaging, and echocardiogram.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

* Pneumonia, other (likely post-obstructive pneumonia)
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
* Pleural effusion, acute
* Systolic and likely diastolic heart failure (HF)
* Acute on chronic HF
* Fluid overload
* Anemia
* Hypocalcemia
* Hyperphosphatemia
* Elevated troponin-T levels
* Abnormal liver function tests (LFTs)

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Vancomycin and cefepime for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)
* Azithromycin to cover atypicals
* Metoprolol for rate control of AFIB
* Pantoprazole for proton pump inhibition
* Heparin sodium for prophylaxis
* Morphine for pain and anxiety
* Lasix for diuresis
* Montelukast, fluticasone, and cobivent for asthma
* Nebulizers with albuterol and ipratropium bromide

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 10.1-11.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.8-11.0 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 120-178 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.3-2.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.13 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 3.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27 mmol/L
* Glucose: 106-125 mg/dL

The patient's radiological findings include:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): worse pulmonary edema
* Computed tomography (CT) imaging: dense, possibly post-obstructive pneumonia

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.1-36.7째C
* Heart rate: 93-110 bpm
* Blood pressure: 143/67-156/96 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25-28 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 91%
* SpO2: 91-94%

The patient's physical examination findings include:

* General: cheerful, oriented, no pain or shortness of breath
* Cardiovascular: irregular rhythm, no murmurs
* Pulmonary: diffuse wheezing bilaterally
* Abdominal: soft, non-tender, non-distended, +bowel sounds
* Extremities: 2+ pitting edema bilaterally in the feet and distal legs

Based on the patient's medical conditions, laboratory results, and radiological findings, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia and fluid overload
* Cardiac arrhythmias, including AFIB and ventricular fibrillation
* Heart failure, including systolic and diastolic HF
* Kidney injury, including acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD)
* Liver injury, including acute liver failure (ALF) and chronic liver disease (CLD)
* Neurological complications, including hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion and embolic phenomena
* Gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
* Endocrine complications, including hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia
* Hematological complications, including anemia and thrombocytopenia

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and radiological findings to prevent and manage these potential complications.

 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE
   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral pulmonary infiltrate.
   Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to have
   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, urine culture
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- f/u IP recs, if any given the patient refused VATS
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn; start 1-2mg IV q4h prn
   -- Haldol for anxiety prn
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs prn (but watch use of albuterol given tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   -- Consider lasix if acute SOB but feel pneumonia is key factor, not
   volume overload (plus Cr bumped today)
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain.
   -- Diltiazem drip previously d/c
ed for rate control
   -- Changed metoprolol 50mg tid to IV 10mg q4h given difficulty taking
   PO
   -- Hope for autodiuresis with better rate control and forward flow;
   hold Lasix diuresis for today, re-evaluate tomorrow
   -- Consider lasix if acute SOB but feel pneumonia is key factor, not
   volume overload (plus Cr bumped today)[]
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.
   - Re-evaluate daily and need for Lasix diuresis; hold for today
   - Consider lasix if acute SOB
   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Haldol PRN
   - EKG today for QT prolongation
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus
   embolic phenomenom d/t afib without anticoagulation. Symptoms resolved
   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient
   - If clinical picture changes, consider CT head
   .
   # End of life care:
   - Palliative care c/s placed and staffed yesterday, f/u recs
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .
   # FEN:  Regular diet
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel regimen PRN
   .
   #. CONTACT: with patient, had friends who are [**Name (NI) 11045**] ([**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 16**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 484**] and

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old male admitted to the ICU with shortness of breath, DOE, and pink frothy sputum production. He has a history of cardiac disease, squamous cell carcinoma on the face, and smoking. The patient has developed pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and a pleural effusion. He has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime for HAP, and azithromycin to cover atypicals. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypoxia, which worsens his anxiety and decreases his SpO2.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is severe, and there is a risk of progression to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or respiratory failure.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is unstable, and there is a risk of cardiac arrest or stroke.
3. Pleural Effusion: The patient's pleural effusion may worsen, leading to respiratory compromise or cardiac tamponade.
4. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, or cerebral hypoperfusion.
5. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen, leading to pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.
6. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: The patient's diabetes may worsen, leading to diabetic ketoacidosis.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen, leading to hemorrhage or perforation.
8. End-of-Life Care: The patient's condition may deteriorate, leading to the need for end-of-life care.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for pneumonia with vancomycin and cefepime.
2. Monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and consider cardioversion.
3. Manage the patient's pleural effusion with thoracentesis and/or VATS.
4. Monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and consider non-invasive ventilation.
5. Monitor the patient's fluid status and consider diuresis with lasix.
6. Monitor the patient's diabetes and consider insulin therapy.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding and consider endoscopy.
8. Consider end-of-life care and palliative care for the patient.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 87-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and pleural effusion. The patient's condition has been deteriorating, with decreased oxygen saturation overnight and increased respiratory distress. The patient's respiratory status improved with the administration of a neb with albuterol and atrovent.

The patient has a history of cardiac disease, including atrial fibrillation, and is at risk for heart failure. The patient's creatinine level has increased, and the patient has been experiencing pedal edema and rapid weight gain, which may indicate heart failure.

The patient's mental status has been altered, with episodes of agitation and disorientation. The patient's blood pressure has been elevated, and the patient's heart rate has been irregular.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusion put the patient at risk for respiratory failure. The patient's decreased oxygen saturation and increased respiratory distress may indicate that the patient is already experiencing respiratory failure.

4. Stroke: The patient's atrial fibrillation and altered mental status put the patient at risk for stroke.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's pedal edema and rapid weight gain may indicate that the patient is at risk for fluid overload.

The patient's treatment plan should include:

5. Monitoring of the patient's respiratory status with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary

Summary:

The patient is an 87-year-old man with respiratory failure due to multilobar pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and acute pleural effusion. He is currently in the ICU and is not intubated. His oxygen requirement is high, and he is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime. His mental status has improved today.

Physical Examination:

The patient is not in acute distress, with normal vital signs, including a heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 147/76 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 89%. He has symmetric chest expansion and bronchial breath sounds on the left side, with rhonchorous sounds on the left side greater than the right. He has right and left lower extremity edema, with a soft and non-tender abdomen.

Lab Results:

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 10.1, hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 120 K/uL. His serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen is 27 mg/dL. His troponin-T level is 0.13 ng/mL, and his lactic acid level is 1.0 mmol/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his pneumonia is not effectively treated, leading to further hypoxia and potential respiratory arrest.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further cardiac complications, such as stroke or heart failure, if not effectively managed.
3. Pleural Effusion: The patient's acute pleural effusion may worsen if not effectively treated, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential respiratory failure.
4. DVT: The patient's use of prophylactic heparin may increase his risk of developing a deep vein thrombosis, which could lead to further complications if not effectively managed.
5. VAP: The patient's use of a high-flow oxygen device may increase his risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia, which could lead to further respiratory complications if not effectively managed.
6. Infection: The patient's pneumonia may lead to further infection, such as sepsis, if not effectively treated.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and pleural effusion may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or stroke, if not effectively managed.

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral pulmonary infiltrate.
   Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to have
   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, sputum cultures
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- can repeat 20 IV lasix again today, goal -500cc today, given CXR,
   wheeze (?cardiac wheeze), pedal edema
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn 1-2mg IV q4h
   -- consider haldol for anxiety (as anxiety was trigger for hypoxia)
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs standing and prn (but cautious use of albuterol given
   tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain. s/p diltiazem gtt for rate control.
   -- Change IV to PO metoprolol (metoprolol 50mg tid) as taking PO
   without difficulty now
   -- Lasix this AM, as above
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.
   - Lasix as above, diuresis
   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Consider haldol as needed for agitation as that was previously
   related to desats
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus
   embolic phenomenom d/t afib without anticoagulation. Symptoms resolved
   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient
   - If clinical picture changes, consider CT head
   .
   # End of life care:
   - Palliative care c/s placed, f/u recs
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- will hold home PO meds; on SSI
   .
   # FEN:  Regular diet
   .
   #. PPX: home PPI, SQH, bowel regimen
 goal BM today
   .
   #. CONTACT: with patient, had friends who are [**Name (NI) 11045**] ([**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 16**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 484**] and
   [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11046**])
 they were updated yesterday ([**12-27**])
   .
   #. CODE: DNR/DNI.
   #. DISPO: in ICU, pending clinical improvement.

   element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely, and
   would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole lung is
   affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days ago at
   PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis, making
   mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  Re-evaluation of the CT while awaiting
   final read appears as though patient has dense, possibly
   post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient was initially on
   Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this was d/c
   [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When patient
   becomes anxious, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP and azithromycin to cover atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, sputum cultures
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema
   -- can repeat 20 IV lasix again today, goal -500cc today, given CXR,
   wheeze (?cardiac wheeze), pedal edema
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn 1-2mg IV q4h
   -- consider haldol for anxiety (as anxiety was trigger for hypoxia)
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- daily CXR
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- nebs standing and prn (but cautious use of albuterol given
   tachycardia)
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain. s/p diltiazem gtt for rate control.
   -- Change IV to PO metoprolol (metoprolol 50mg tid) as taking PO
   without difficulty now
   -- Lasix this AM, as above
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily

s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
   today and instead attempt to rate control a fib with RVR to increase
   forward flow and promote auto-diuresis.

   - Monitor I/O to ensure patient does not go into fluid overload & go
   into flash pulmonary edema
   - Morphine PRN as above
   .
   # Agitation: Patient agitated when SpO2 decreases.
   - Consider haldol as needed for agitation as that was previously
   related to desats
   - Reorient frequently
   .
   # Disorientation: Patient, while hypoxic, felt vertical while was
   horizontal in bed. Consider hypoxic cerebral hypoperfusion, verus

   now with improved SpO2.
   - Reorient

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is experiencing respiratory distress and pneumonia, with a CXR showing complete opacification of the left lung and increased right upper lobe consolidation.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFIB) with rapid ventricular rate (RVR), and new left ventricular hypokinesis was detected on TTE. The patient has pedal edema and rapid weight gain, suggesting possible heart failure.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has a tenuous fluid status, with a fluid balance of -1,560 mL and pedal edema.
* Renal: The patient has elevated creatinine (2.3 mg/dL) and decreased ejection fraction (LVEF).
* Metabolic: The patient has hyperglycemia (156 mg/dL) and is on insulin therapy.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, which is not delirium, and has been disoriented in the past.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current status include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and pneumonia can lead to respiratory failure, which may require intubation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's AFIB with RVR and left ventricular hypokinesis can lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or even sudden cardiac death.
* Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and decreased ejection fraction can lead to renal failure, which may require dialysis.
* Infection: The patient's pneumonia and pleural effusion can lead to secondary infections, such as sepsis or empyema.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's altered mental status and disorientation can lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or bowel obstruction.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for pneumonia
* Rate control for AFIB with RVR
* Diuresis with Lasix to manage fluid status
* Morphine for SOB and anxiety
* Consideration of haldol for agitation
* Daily CXR to monitor lung status
* CPAP as needed
* Palliative care consultation

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and their disposition is pending clinical improvement.

Summary:

The patient is a 87-year-old male with a history of cardiac disease, squamous cell carcinoma on the face, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted with respiratory distress, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He has been treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and antifungals, and is currently receiving high-flow nasal cannula oxygen and nebulized treatments. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, blood pressure of 107/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 92%. His physical examination is notable for crackles and rhonchi in the lungs, and 2+ pitting edema in the feet and distal legs.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to worsen due to the presence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and the patient's history of smoking.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he may require intubation and mechanical ventilation if his oxygenation and ventilation deteriorate.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, or stroke.
4. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's history of smoking and the presence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates may increase the risk of pulmonary embolism.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's fluid overload and the presence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates may increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
6. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and the presence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates may increase the risk of sepsis.
7. End-of-Life Care: The patient's advanced age and tenuous health may indicate the need for end-of-life care, including palliative care and hospice services.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antivirals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation and mechanical ventilation if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke and systemic embolism.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid status closely and consider diuresis with Lasix if necessary.
5. Consider CT imaging of the chest and abdomen to evaluate the patient's pulmonary and abdominal status.
6. Consider palliative care and hospice services to support the patient's end-of-life care.

   ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 87 y/o male with cardiac history as well as squamous
   cell CA on face, admitted with SOB/DOE x 3 days w/ pink frothy sputum
   production and white out of left lung.
   .
   #. SHORTNESS OF BREATH: Patient with unilateral multi-lobar pulmonary
   infiltrate. Less likely CHF b/c of unilateral nature, though appears to
   have element of volume overload; parapneumonic effusion most likely,
   and would consider post-obstructive PNA given degree to which whole
   lung is affect and smoking history (thought had a normal PE four days
   ago at PCP's office per the pt).  Also with question of hemotpysis,
   making mass and PE a possibility (especially with the hypoxia).  S/p
   thoracentesis with CT imaging , initially believed to show loculated
   pleural effusion, final read pending.  TTE showed no pleural effusion
   or aortic stenosis, but did show new [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular hypokinesis.  IP
   evaluated patient and recommended VATS for loculated pleural effusion,
   which the patient refused.  His CT shows a dense pneumonia. Patient was
   initially on Azithro/Ceftriaxone for empiric treatment of CAP, but this
   was d/c
ed [**12-26**] and patient was started on Vanc/Cefepime for HAP. When
   patient becomes anxious or removes his O2 mask, SpO2 decreases.
   -- Continue Vanc/Cefepime for HAP
   - If spikes, add levoflox
   -- patient is s/p 5 day course of azithromycin (finished [**12-30**]) for
   coverage of atypicals
   -- f/u blood cultures, sputum cultures
   -- daily CXR
   -- nebs standing and prn (but cautious use of albuterol given
   tachycardia)
   -- Given [**Hospital1 **]-v hypokinesis and likely diastolic and systolic
   dysfunction, monitor fluid status carefully to ensure patient does not
   go into flash pulmonary edema; lasix prn to keep pt in negative fluid
   balance.
   -- morphine for SOB and anxiety prn 1-2mg IV q4h
   -- consider haldol for anxiety (as anxiety was trigger for hypoxia)
   -- CPAP as needed
   -- cont home montelukast, fluticasone, cobivent
   -- Patient does not wish to be intubated
   .
   #. AFIB:  In afib with RVR.  Consider HF as a trigger given significant
   pedal edema and rapid weight gain. s/p diltiazem gtt for rate control.
   -- Continue metoprolol 50mg TID
   -- diuresis with Lasix prn
   -- Not on anticoagulation for fall risk and ? GIB hx.
   -- Continue ASA 325mg daily
   .
   #. Systolic and likely diastolic HF:  Given BNP >[**Numeric Identifier 11043**], weight gain,
   pitting edema b/l, and elevated Cr, patient appears he is in acute on
   chronic HF, though fluid status is difficult to assess in this
   patient.  Given patient
s age and tenuous health, hold Lasix diuresis
